Net worth is a measure of your financial health. It\'s calculated by subtracting your total liabilities (what you owe) from your total assets (what you own).

Assets include:
- Liquid assets (cash, savings, current accounts)
- Investment assets (stocks, bonds, ISAs, property investments)
- Retirement assets (workplace pensions, SIPPs, personal pensions)
- Personal assets (home, car, valuables, collectibles)

Liabilities include:
- Short-term debts (credit cards, overdrafts, outstanding council tax)
- Long-term debts (mortgages, student loans, car finance)

For example, if you have %1$s500,000 in assets and %1$s200,000 in liabilities, your net worth is %1$s300,000.

A positive net worth means you own more than you owe, which is a sign of financial stability. Tracking your net worth over time helps you measure your financial progress and make informed decisions about your money.

A mortgage is a loan used to purchase property. The property itself serves as security for the loan, meaning the lender can repossess if you fail to make payments.

How it works: When you take out a mortgage, you borrow money to buy a property and repay it over a set period (usually 15-35 years) through monthly payments. Each payment includes:
- Principal: The amount borrowed
- Interest: The cost of borrowing
- Council Tax: Annual local authority tax (paid separately but included in affordability)
- Buildings Insurance: Required by most lenders
- Contents Insurance: Optional but recommended

For example, if you buy a home for %1$s300,000 with a %1$s60,000 deposit, you\'ll borrow %1$s240,000. At a 4%% interest rate over 25 years, your monthly repayment will be approximately %1$s1,300.

A tax calculator helps you estimate your income tax liability based on your income, tax code, and allowances. This helps you plan your finances and understand your take-home pay.

How it works: Enter your annual income, tax code, and any deductions. The calculator estimates your tax liability using UK tax bands and shows your effective tax rate. Remember that National Insurance is calculated separately.

For example, if you earn %1$s40,000 annually with the standard personal allowance of %1$s12,570, your taxable income is %1$s27,430, resulting in approximately %1$s5,486 in income tax (plus National Insurance contributions).
